greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the number of positive integers k such that k*(k+1) divides n.
comment: The usual OEIS policy is not to include sequences like this where alternate terms are zero; this is an exception.
link: Ray Chandler, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
P. Erdos and R. R. Hall, On some unconventional problems on the divisors of integers, J. Austral. Math. Soc., Ser. A, 25, 479-485 (1978).
MathOverflow, On the number of consecutive divisors of an integer
formula: G.f.: Sum_{n>=1} x^(n*(n+1))/(1-x^(n*(n+1))). - _Joerg Arndt_, Jan 30 2011 [modified by _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 14 2021]
a(n) = A000005(n) - A137921(n), where A137921(n) is the number of maximal runs of successive divisors of n. - _Gus Wiseman_, Oct 15 2019
example: The divisors of 20 are 1,2,4,5,10,20. Of these there are two that are of the form k(k+1): 2 = 1*2 and 20 = 4*5. So a(2) = 2.
mathematica: a = {}; For[n = 1, n < 90, n++, k = 1; co = 0; While[k < Sqrt[n], If[IntegerQ[ n/(k*(k + 1))], co++ ]; k++ ]; AppendTo[a, co]]; a (* _Stefan Steinerberger_, May 27 2007 *)
xref: First appearance of n is A287142(n), with sorted version A328450.
The longest run of divisors of n has length A055874(n).
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, May 26 2007
